perturbation.original_text:
Manufacturer represents, warrants and covenants to Customer that:

Manufacturer has reviewed its supply chain security procedures and that these procedures and their implementation are, and shall remain during the Term of this Agreement, in accordance with the importer security criteria set forth by the "C-TPAT." Manufacturer represents and warrants that it has developed and implemented, or shall develop and implement within sixty (60) calendar days of its execution of this Agreement, procedures for periodically reviewing and, if necessary, improving its supply chain security procedures to assure compliance with C-TPAT minimum security criteria.
perturbation.changed_text:
Manufacturer represents, warrants and covenants to Customer that:

Manufacturer has reviewed its supply chain security procedures.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the text regarding compliance with C-TPAT and the implementation of review procedures, the contract no longer ensures adherence to supply chain security standards. This omission creates a legal risk, as companies operating in international trade are generally expected to maintain adequate security measures to prevent illegal activities such as smuggling or terrorism. Failure to adhere to these expectations may lead to penalties and liabilities.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism (C-TPAT) guidelines and related international trade security regulations.

perturbation.original_text: Customer may reject any Non-Complying Product or Product that is not delivered to Customer in accordance with this Agreement by providing written notice of such rejection to Manufacturer within seventy-five (75) days following Customer's receipt of any Delivery of Product hereunder; provided, however, that Customer may, until the expiry date for a Product, provide notice of rejection of any Delivery of such Product having (i) latent defects, (ii) any defects that are not reasonably discoverable by Customer through standard inspection and testing of Products or (iii) defects caused by the breach by Manufacturer of any of its representations or warranties under this Agreement (collectively, "Latent Defects"); provided, further, that, and notwithstanding the foregoing, Customer shall notify Manufacturer within sixty (60) days after Customer first becomes aware of any such Latent Defect.
perturbation.changed_text: Customer may reject any Non-Complying Product or Product that is not delivered to Customer in accordance with this Agreement by providing written notice of such rejection to Manufacturer within seventy-five (75) days following Customer's receipt of any Delivery of Product hereunder;.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting the text relating to Latent Defects, the customer is no longer able to reject products where the defects are not immediately obvious. Many jurisdictions have laws protecting consumers against latent defects in products. By removing this, the contract creates legal risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied warranty of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose (Uniform Commercial Code).

perturbation.original_text: Manufacturer shall maintain detailed Records with respect to Product Materials, Buy-Sell Materials, and Customer-Supplied Materials usage and finished Product production in accordance with the Quality Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 'Quality Agreement' clause weakens the manufacturing standards. The records clause lacks sufficient details to comply with regulatory standards. Many jurisdictions have laws relating to product and supply chain record-keeping. By removing this text, the contract creates legal risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 21 CFR Part 211 - Current Good Manufacturing Practice Regulations
